Here is a life of rare and moving

half the artistic celebrities of Europe.
The fascinating unreality of the stage
glows like a spotlight on some of her
characters. Lauded by J. B. Priestley,
krnold Bennett and the London Times,
the central charm of the book lies in
the author's personality which shines
forth from every page.

the frosh than the crash of weighty
words of wisdom upon their ears.
We are weak, though. We shall advise—once. And, what is worse, our
admonition is a don't. It is: "Don't
try to be a 'big man' on the campus.
Activities, most of the saner observers
of undergraduate life will aver, are
a salutary force in the life of the undergrad, but there is no more real
waste of the opportunity that college
offers than to tackle more activities
than you can handle. For all, except
potential Thomas A. Edisons, two activities should be a man's limit. If you
attempt more, the chance are about
five to one that you will either fail
to get the most out of your studies
or that you will bungle the activities.
You will probably do both."
Here our advice stops. Take it or
leave it. Go out for one or two activyou will really enjoy the expekeep your eyes the same

gether to create the play as the playwrite conceived it. His greatest joy

So they come. Every year applications of hopefuls pour in. Only a few
can be accomodated. Some come, grow
discouraged, and leave. Others find
Openings in New York, Hollywood, or
soMe other Little Theatre group. A
few are successful as a result. Many
fit into parts in stock companies. And
then, of course, there are those who
stick. Stick because this gives them a
Manner of living, a reason for living. To work and be always working,
to find something to be done everyMinute. Satisfied with the theatre
they have got, glad to produce the
great plays of masters, and equally
happy to try some one of the many
Manuscripts which pour into the mail
boxes, they try plays of seasons ago,
or of seasons to come. They welcome
any audiences, by not caring for the
audiences.

Baltimore at the Auditorium, for
two performances on November 18. In
the afternoon, the play will be "The

is the opening bill of the Hopkins
Playhouse, under the direction of Dr.

pected From The
Fraternity Teams
With play starting today in the
fraternity touch football league, Pi
Lambda Phi will defend its championship. Phi Psi, Omicron Kappa
Omicron, Phi Sigma Delta and Sigma Phi Epsilon will provide opposition.
This league is part of the intramural program, and each fraternity
is represented. There will be two
divisions, eight teams in each. Seven
games will be played by each entry.
On the Tuesday preceeding the
Thanksgiving holidays activities will
reach a climax. All sixteen teams
are to play on that date on the regular football field and the one beside
Levering Hall. After Thanksgiving there is scheduled a play off between the winners of each division.
A plaque will be awarded to the victorious fraters. Also points per contest will go towards the winning of
the Turbyville trophy.
Referees Chosen
At a meting of the Fraternity Athletic Council held last Wednesday,
plans for the year were discussed.
Besides this, rules were approved
and referees and supervisors appointed.
Touch football is the same as the
regulation game except in a few
respects. Only seven men compose a
team and five downs are allowed
in an attempt for a touchdown. The
time of the game is 40 minutes,
played in two halves. Minor changes
from varsity football restrict the
dangers of the game.

Jays' Defense Good
Hopkins play was not completely
lacking in brilliancy. During the
course of the contest the line demonstrated remarkable ability to tighten
up in the clutches. Despite the
fact that Lehigh was far superior
both in weight and offensive prowess, the Blue Jay linesmen, led by

very well. More than a few times the
Lehigh backs were forced to fumble
and thrown for heavy losses. The
Hopkins boys played hard and tackled hard. Their defense was just
about as good as their opponents'.

they could do nothing. Kahl was
about the most effective runner in
the backfield. Only one pass was
completed, and that for no gain.

Regular Course To
versed This Week For
First Time

The Jay cross country men are
now beginning to hit their stride.
Coach Hambleton held the first time
trials Friday afternoon, October 9.
The distance covered was only one
mile, but was certainly an acid test
considering the tough hill in back
of

Wyman Park. The competitive

run is usually between four and five
miles, and the hill and dalers should
be ready for it in a week or so.
Many berths are still vacant, and
Coach Hambleton urges all sturdy,
long-winded men to report for practice any afternoon at four. The workouts will help those who are going
out for winter sports to get in shape.
The first obstacle is Lehigh University, and it ought to be a close
and interesting meet. Our team is
host, and the date is October 14.

try to be a 'big man' on the campus.
Activities, most of the saner observers
of undergraduate life will aver, are
a salutary force in the life of the undergrad, but there is no more real

offers than to tackle more activities
than you can handle. For all, except
potential Thomas A. Edisons, two activities should be a man's limit. If you
attempt more, the chance are about
five to one that you will either fail
to get the most out of your studies
or that you will bungle the activities.
You will probably do both."
Here our advice stops. Take it or

a group matter; of people working to-

gether to create the play as the playwrite conceived it. His greatest joy
is when some awkward youngster succeeds in feeling the part through his
whole body, and at last really belongs
to it. And then to see the effect of that
on the whole troupe.
So they come. Every year applications of hopefuls pour in. Only a few
can be accomodated. Some come, grow
discouraged, and leave. Others find
Openings in New York, Hollywood, or
soMe other Little Theatre group. A
few are successful as a result. Many
fit into parts in stock companies. And
then, of course, there are those who
stick. Stick because this gives them a
Manner of living, a reason for living. To work and be always working,
to find something to be done everyMinute. Satisfied with the theatre
they have got, glad to produce the
great plays of masters, and equally
happy to try some one of the many
Manuscripts which pour into the mail
boxes, they try plays of seasons ago,
or of seasons to come. They welcome
any audiences, by not caring for the
audiences.
This troupe will be seen here in
Baltimore at the Auditorium, for
two performances on November 18. In
the afternoon, the play will be "The
Rhiperor's New Clothes." In the evening, Bernard Shaw's biting satire,
:Getting Married," will be shown. This
is the opening bill of the Hopkins
Playhouse, under the direction of Dr.
N. B. Fagin.

pected From The
Fraternity Teams
With play starting today in the
fraternity touch football league, Pi
Lambda Phi will defend its championship. Phi Psi, Omicron Kappa
Omicron, Phi Sigma Delta and Sigma Phi Epsilon will provide opposition.
This league is part of the intramural program, and each fraternity
is represented. There will be two
divisions, eight teams in each. Seven
games will be played by each entry.
On the Tuesday preceeding the
Thanksgiving holidays activities will
reach a climax. All sixteen teams
are to play on that date on the regular football field and the one beside
Levering Hall. After Thanksgiving there is scheduled a play off between the winners of each division.
A plaque will be awarded to the victorious fraters. Also points per contest will go towards the winning of
the Turbyville trophy.
Referees Chosen
At a meting of the Fraternity Athletic Council held last Wednesday,
plans for the year were discussed.
Besides this, rules were approved
and referees and supervisors appointed.
Touch football is the same as the
regulation game except in a few
respects. Only seven men compose a
team and five downs are allowed
in an attempt for a touchdown. The
time of the game is 40 minutes,
played in two halves. Minor changes
from varsity football restrict the
dangers of the game.

Jays' Defense Good
Hopkins play was not completely
lacking in brilliancy. During the
course of the contest the line demonstrated remarkable ability to tighten
up in the clutches. Despite the
fact that Lehigh was far superior

they could do nothing. Kahl was
about the most effective runner in
the backfield. Only one pass was
completed, and that for no gain.

Regular Course To
versed This Week For
First Time

The Jay cross country men are
now beginning to hit their stride.
Coach Hambleton held the first time
trials Friday afternoon, October 9.
The distance covered was only one
mile, but was certainly an acid test
considering the tough hill in back
of

Wyman Park. The competitive

run is usually between four and five
miles, and the hill and dalers should
be ready for it in a week or so.
Many berths are still vacant, and
Coach Hambleton urges all sturdy,
long-winded men to report for practice any afternoon at four. The workouts will help those who are going
out for winter sports to get in shape.
The first obstacle is Lehigh University, and it ought to be a close
and interesting meet. Our team is
host, and the date is October 14.
